MARSHA BLACKBURN">Mrs. Blackburn [presiding]. All right. The committee will reconvene, and I recognize myself for 5 minutes for an opening statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">And I want to welcome you all. I apologize to everyone. We thought we had votes at 10:00, and then it was going to be 10:10 and come on back over here--you know, it's just one of those days--a getaway day, an omnibus day, and we are going to go ahead and start this hearing because you never know when the bell is going to go off.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="HON. MARSHA BLACKBURN">A little less than 2 months ago, we did our first legislative hearing. This is our second. We sat here in this room discussing 25 pieces of legislation addressing broadband infrastructure, representing all the views on the table.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="HON. These illegal broadcasts deprive Americans of important programming provided by legitimate license holders serving the public interest.</paragraph>

<opening>Prepared statement of Hon. Marsha Blackburn</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">It's high time we pay more attention to the harm being done to consumers and broadcasters alike.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">Good morning and welcome to our second legislative hearing of 2018. A little less than 2 months ago, we sat here in this room discussing 25 pieces of legislation addressing broadband infrastructure representing all the views on the table. Last month, we shocked the naysayers by shepherding many of the subcommittee's top priorities through the full committee unanimously in RAY BAUM'S Act. Today, just as that package is about to head toward the President's desk, we've got four more bipartisan bills that address everything from combating illegal pirate radio to identifying ways technology can help prevent suicide across the country. I couldn't be more pleased with the work of members of the subcommittee and all the important initiatives we've got going on this year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">I'd also like to commend Congressman Stewart on being a champion for the National Suicide Hotline Improvement Act, which currently has 78 cosponsors, including seven of our subcommittee members: Mr. Bilirakis, Ms. Clarke, Ms. Eshoo, Mr. Flores, Mr. McKinley, Mr. Rush, and Mr. Tonko. Suicide is the 10th leading cause of death in Tennessee, and this legislation would make it easier for those facing a mental crisis to get the help they need with a dedicated N-1-1 number.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">We'll also be discussing Mr. McKinley and Mr. Welch's bill, the Rural Reasonable and Comparable Wireless Access Act, which takes a new perspective on getting wireless broadband out to rural areas. This subcommittee has long been looking for ways to close the digital divide, and today we will be discussing another potential solution.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">And speaking of infrastructure, another bill which could help spur investment in broadband infrastructure is Mr. Latta and Mr. Schrader's Small Entity Regulatory Relief Opportunity Act, or SERRO. Small entities across the country, regardless of technology, face miles of red tape at the FCC to comply with regulations designed for large providers. Money that these small, often rural entities spend on complying with regulations is money that they could instead be investing in broadband deployment, and it's important for us and for the Commission to keep this in mind instead of assuming that one size should fit all in every case.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">Finally, we'll be discussing Mr. Lance and Mr. Tonko's PIRATE Act, which many Members of the subcommittee have helped work on; including Mr. Collins, Mr. Tonko, Mr. Bilirakis, Mr. Green, Mr. Moulton, Mr. King, and Mrs. Dingell. Illegal pirate radio disrupts access to important public safety communications, including our Nation's Emergency Alert System and critical aviation frequencies. These illegal broadcasts deprive Americans of important programming provided by legitimate license holders serving the public interest. It's high time we pay more attention to the harm being done to consumers and broadcasters alike.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">I'd like to thank our witnesses for being here, and with that I will yield 1 minute to the vice chairman of the subcommittee, Mr. Lance.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn">Mrs. Blackburn. I'd like to thank our witnesses for being here, and Mr. Lance is not here, so would anyone like the 1 minute?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Hon. Marsha Blackburn"> Mr. Latta, you're recognized. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Latta</speaker> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Latta">Well, thank you, Madam Chair, and I appreciate you holding today's hearing on these four bills, including my own, the Small Entity Regulatory Relief Opportunity Act, or</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Latta">Recognizing that small businesses are the engines of our economy and do not require the same level of regulatory oversight as large entities, the gentleman from Oregon, Mr. Schrader, and I put forth a commonsense proposal to create a regulatory environment that encourages innovation, spurs competition, and fosters consumer choice.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Latta">SERRO offers a pathway for regulatory relief for small entities by directing the FCC to streamline their existing waiver process. This will benefit small business and their customers by providing greater certainty, fewer costs, and administrative efficiency.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Latta">Since introducing H.R. 3787, Mr. Schrader and I have made countless efforts to consider all stakeholder feedback and input, and today's discussion is a continuation of those efforts.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Latta">I look forward to hearing from our panelists, and I thank the gentlelady, the chair of the subcommittee, for yielding.</paragraph>

<opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. MICHAEL F. DOYLE, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE COMMONWEALTH OF PENNSYLVANIA</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. MICHAEL F. DOYLE"> Mr. Doyle, you're recognized. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Thank you, Madam Chair, for holding this hearing, and thank you to the witnesses for appearing before us today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Today we are considering four pieces of legislation. In particular, I am happy to see before us a bill by my good friend Peter Welch, H.R. 2903, the Rural Reasonable and Comparable Wireless Act.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Doyle">This bipartisan legislation seeks to establish national standards for mobile service, mobile data service, and broadband services in rural America that are comparable to those in urban America.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Doyle">I know this is an issue that my friend and colleague is very passionate about, and as this bill points out, under the Communications Act, Congress tasked the FCC with ensuring that rural areas had similar access and availability of service as their urban counterparts.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Doyle">But I don't have to tell anyone here that we have fallen short of that goal. Get on a highway that isn't the I-95 corridor, and wireless service gets spotty fast.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Or move from Pittsburgh or DC to rural Tennessee and try to get fiber internet. We need to make sure that people in rural America can get the same kind of widespread high-speed access as we have in urban areas and along urban corridors.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Doyle">I am proud the committee Democrats have proposed a plan with Ranking Member Pallone's LIFT America Act that seeks to close this gap with a $40 billion investment in capital investments.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Congressman Lance and I have also introduced the AIRWAVES Act along with a number of our colleagues on both sides of the aisle that sets aside 10 percent of the revenue from the spectrum auctions set out in the bill for deployment of broadband infrastructure in unserved and underserved communities in rural America.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Another bill we have under discussion today is Congresswoman Bernice Johnson's National Suicide Hotline Improvement Act, which would require the FCC to work in coordination with SAMHSA to explore the feasibility of a three- digit dialing code similar to 9-1-1 or 3-1-1 for suicide prevention.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Doyle">This legislation passed by UC in the Senate, a seemingly rare feat these days, and I hope we can continue to move this important legislation forward.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Doyle">We are also discussing a bill on unlicensed radio broadcasts today, and while I have heard anecdotes that there is a problem on the rise in major cities like New York and Miami, I am concerned that the proposed solution is to increase fines for these broadcasts tenfold.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Years ago, I worked with Congressman Lee Terry on the Low Power FM Radio legislation. We saw that there was an issue of illegal broadcasts but also that there weren't many opportunities for communities around the country to express themselves on the air.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Doyle">We sought to address this by increasing the opportunities available to these communities by opening a Low Power FM application window, which resulted in thousands of new stations across the country.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Doyle">As we consider this legislation, I think we need to balance the legitimate concerns of broadcast licensees with the limited opportunities for expression available to some communities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Doyle">My hope is as we consider this bill we can take an approach that addresses both groups' needs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Doyle">And the last bill we are considering today is Congressman Latta's H.R. 3787, the Small Entity Regulatory Relief Opportunity Act.</paragraph>

<opening>Prepared statement of Hon. Michael F. Doyle</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Hon. Michael F. Doyle">I am very concerned about this bill. The way that it is drafted would open up a huge regulatory hole at the FCC and would enable companies with over a billion dollars in revenue to be exempted from a wide range of rules intended to protect consumers and, to be honest, small businesses as well.I am very skeptical about the merits and need for this legislation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Hon. Michael F. Doyle">Thank you, Madam Chairman, for holding this hearing, and thank you to the witnesses for appearing before us today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Hon. Michael F.
